answers.explanation:
![](/content/media/retina-21-2.webp)

**Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment secondary to a full thickness macular hole.**

The hypo-reflective space underneath the retina consists of sub-retinal fluid which connects to the vitreous cavity (above the macular hole). The RPE and choroidal layers are not included on this OCT scan as the neuro-sensory retina is detached. Associated intraretinal fluid and presence of vitreous debris around the macula hole are also evident on OCT.

questions.title: Question 1
questions.text: Based on the OCT, what is the diagnosis?

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text:
What features on this OCT scan indicate that this is likely a chronic process?

![](/content/media/retina-21-1.webp)

answers.explanation:
![](/content/media/retina-21-4.webp)

Features of chronicity in this OCT include presence of intra-retinal edema, a smooth outer retinal layer (with no corrugations), and presence of vitreous debris.

References:

Auger G, Winder S. Spectral domain OCT: an aid to diagnosis and surgical planning of retinal detachments. Journal of ophthalmology. 2011 Dec 29;2011.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text:
Surgery was performed. Post-operatively, his visual acuity was 20/200. The OCT below demonstrates the post-operative appearance of the retina. Based on the OCT, what are some potential visual prognostic findings?

![](/content/media/retina-21-3.webp)

answers.explanation:
![](/content/media/retina-21-5.webp)

Predictors of poor BCVA include disruption of ellipsoid zone and external limiting membrane, increased outer nuclear layer thickness, and retinal atrophy (decreased average and central macular thickness values). These are all features that are present in the OCT above, explaining the poor post-operative visual acuity of our patient.
​
References:

Saber EE, Bayoumy AS, Elmohamady MN, Faramawi HM. Macular microstructure and visual acuity after macula-off retinal detachment repair by 23-gauge vitrectomy plus silicone endotamponade. Clinical Ophthalmology (Auckland, NZ). 2018;12:2005.
